title.narrative: Ethics in Public Governance Training for Public Servants and Related Professionals

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to introduce the participants to viewing governance in the perspective of ethics and integrity. The main objective of the project is to increase the professional competence by advancing the concrete skills and recognition of eth ical issues in the professionals employed in the public service through a structured training programme.During the 7 months of the project CSS will prepare hold and report on a semester-long training course for members of the police the prosecution the jud iciary taxation authorities and members of the Anti-Corruption Agency focusing on the main ethical underpinnings of governance and public administration horizontal and vertical dimensions of public administration and decision- making the relationship betwe en legality and integrity in the exercise of public administration the main definitions and perceptions of ethics in governance in transitional societies. The sessions will also cover the main typologies of ethics and their consequences for the particular contexts and methods of governance in the areas covered by the target groups for the participants. The curriculum for the course will provide in introduction to the essential integrity-based regulatory themes for public administration thus fa cilitating the ongoing effort to re-position public sector controls from the strictly legal-positivistic system (based solely on criminal justice) to include a complementary integrity-based dimension of regulation which is a recognised priority o f the Serbian government.The specific activities will include preparation and recruitment during the first two months of the project training that will run month 3 through month 6 of the project and evaluation reporting and publication of results on the w eb site which will take up month 7 of the project.The project will include a Finnish component in the training itself through the inclusion of two Finnish expert lecturers in the curriculum. The rationale for this aspect of the project is that Finland is o ne of the countries that are ranked as de facto corruption-free with transparency and institutional integrity standards and policies that are capable of serving as examples for the development of important ethics criteria and practices in Serbia.
